I remember a discussion with my professor gender and diversity on my final exam, about how the "embodied truth" Donna Hadaway, and the intersectional thinkers who succeeded her, gives rise to a highly subjective counterpoint to the dominant, universalist narrative. Yet where the dominant narrative has girded itself with science and theory and norms and traditions, these Other perspectives are singular, personal and contextual. In other words, it has become annoyingly easy to say "you cannot know what it's like unless you lived the experience."
These lived qualitative experiences had to make the transition to the quantitative general truths, for them to be integrated into, and displace, our patriarchal knowledge structure. And the only way to go this, as my professor agreed, was by moving back and forth like a swinging pendulum, using stories to inspire data gathering and quantitative research, and vice versa.
Over the years I often quoted Alexis toqueville's the tyranny of the majority is no democracy. I embraced the progressive ideal of representativeness in democracy, however without a clear end point. Quota would lead the change, and merit would follow. But what is this merit?
Looking back, I'm still conflicted about these ideas. Are there unknowable perspectives, and how should democracies account for them. "Woke" identity politics are balkanising the "agora" of free speech and replacing individual human rights with protections for group identities. Social media are fanning the flames.
Link this with the experiences as a "universalist" immigrant in a country proud of its heritage, its heritage and idiosyncraties.
Where they confirm the stereotypes, it is sometimes hard not to criticize the cultural hangups. The navelgazing is well intended.
Friends with an ideological commitment to openness and tolerance, albeit in theory, often take their tastes and preferences as norms and conventions. Their progressive ideals hardly translate in an interest in intercultural exchanges, learning about others in a non patronising way.
It often makes me feel as if I skipped a part in my development.
It's funny how social norms have this quiet insistence. Norms, customs, rituals, but also taboos, shame, collective myopia.
However, I forgive my friends for the affinity with their own kind. Some cultural preferences and tastes seem universal to them. Some of mine strike them as odd, banal, or worse still, foreign.
But there's a sensuous level of reality, a reality that rings true, because of an affectionate relationship with peers, an identification with a group, with the like-minded. Their loyalty to "the home team" trumps the universalist idealism. Both are values, however only universalism has a broad moral appeal. Some would point to Burke's idea of natural society, the affections that bind us, and the many unwritten rules, norms and conventions that govern our lives in liberal democracy. His notion of allegiances with the "British gentlemen" in America still feels familiar.

Theory of change Vs emotive storytelling
causality and emotive language in philanthropy
The big challenge in social enterprise is to reconcile two distinct linguistic registers: the theoretical, causal reasoning on the one hand, and the emotive, psychological on the other.
The help philanthropist are paying for is often intangible, eg. self-confidence, social connections, social mobility etc. Yet the social organisations are bogged down in day to day considerations, managing flows of money and people etc, to such extent that they don't have the capacity to look over the horizon and imaginatively conceive a long term psychological impact of their endeavours on their beneficiaries. Let alone form testable hypotheses and create iterative series of changes.
As a foundation it is important not to shoehorn itself in a Theory of Change as it only exists for handing out money. It is far more effective to set out its process of selection and evaluation, as a series of touch points in which the foundation can increase its impact, both on the subject matter (its ultimate beneficiaries) and the people it supports and mobilises. Ultimately, the true catalyst will be its coaching and support on the human level towards, 1. articulating a vision on outcomes, and 2. set out the activities in steps to achieve this vision. A vision of outcomes should based on the entrepreneurs deeply felt intuitions and convictions of social justice. These may not be particularly coherent, complete, and or consistent as in a scientific theory, and for that reason I think there's a lot in active listening and coaching towards a more coherent vision before working out the evidence base and the testable parts of the hypothesis. The first step is returned to life feelings, to get back in touch with the original intuitions that led to the entrepreneurial drive.  They may have seen something with thought something or experienced something throughout their early childhood, however, whatever it is, that experience has to be relived before it can be translated into theory.  It is important here to go beyond intellectual curiosity and listen out empathically for the uniqueness of the experience. Often these experiences are ridden by doubt and feelings of insecurity.  Time has brought to bare nativities and unfounded assumptions. They are considered too personal, too fragile to be included in a pitch. Yet  understanding them is essential to steer the social entrepreneur towards impact. For the further development of the entrepreneur, it is also important. In order to receive recognition for that original intuition, to keep the practical day-to-day considerations aligned with the deeper sense of identity,  it is important to have a kind relationship with the origin.
I would also link this with the distinction that the impact management project makes, ie. that we should distinguish targets from intentions. An overarching intention may be to resolve an intractable societal problem, say educational inequality, yet once the intervention is fleshed out in a theory, targets can be defined in a way that can exist independently alongside an intention.
In summary, part of the job of coaching the storytelling of the social entrepreneur is to guide them towards targets. Another part of it is to reacquaint them with their original intentions,  rekindle the original drive, and shore up the identity of the organisation - as its identity is the best source for organisational culture, values, ambitions, and its place in the world.

You don't have to go far to see this - Flanders, for example, is still considered a tiny region in a French-speaking country with a funny language a bit like Welsh or Breton. Its centre is French-speaking, with its colonial reach, its history, its aristocratic grandeur. In this telling the Flemish are the passers-by of history. The ignorance around its history also surrounds the linguistic diversity. That Flemish consist of a group of (Dutch) dialects is an aberration in the eyes of the imperialistic mind. In English, regional differences are frowned upon. Just as its broad-brush-stroke history is still happily idealised as a patriotic tale, linguistic standardisation is a hallmark of cultural identity.

text.3702:
A reflection on my failed novel
- i travelled 18 months with the idea of writing a book
- i thought cs was a great idea but also saw lots of people desperate to believe in something greater who latched onto CS.
- at its peak cs was a community of 10 or 100s of thousands of people
- after I came back i wrote a book about this experience
- by the time i finished cs had lost its shine. People had largely stopped believing.
- I then edited away the references to cs and made it abstracter about traveling in general.
- I added much more focus on the universalism of travel and personal development
- but by the time this edit was done it was the end of the pandemic and publishers were very selective. I got refused 8 times and gave up.
text.3703:
A philosophy on being useful
NOT: If your status is low, try lots of low status work. Keep your head down and get in.
BUT: Try upping the status of what you do in what you say, how it matters, especially to the person you're saying it to.
NOT: Duty, service and loyalty; but: a "strategy of appearances".
Closing: integrity is important. But just like opportunism is what defines business sense, a rigid adherence to social norms will handicap your search for purposeful work. People are instinctive creatures, chimps, and they love to judge you as a tool that is useful for some specific tasks.

Voor boek:
Mathieu heeft een positieve intentie nodig. Het lukt niet altijd, maar hij probeert, en dat is het belangrijkste.
Zelf probeerde ik Europa van binnenuit te leren kennen. Ik wou de cultuur via de taal leren kennen; de eigentijdse cultuur, niet het sediment dat werd opgespaard door musea of de cultuur die in de populaire verbeelding wordt verkondigd, waar een fragiele eigenwaarde en een nood aan vaderlandse geschiedenis nog steeds doorwegen. Ik wou de progressieve, hybride cultuur leren kennen - daar zat mijn eigen positieve, nobele intentie.
